Situation1: They develop a floor plan for a new office, ensuring workspaces accommodate employees’ needs efficiently.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story:
I spent the morning hunched over blueprints, sketching out the new office layout. As an architect, I’m trained to anticipate every need—clear walkways, accessible desks, enough light for everyone. My mind is always on function, on making sure every detail serves the people who’ll use the space. Later, I rushed to the polling station, ballot in hand, feeling the weight of civic duty. When I handed over my envelope, the poll worker frowned and pointed out a smudge on my signature. “Could you re-sign this? Otherwise, your vote might not count.” 

I hesitated. As an architect, I’m meticulous—every mark matters, every instruction followed to the letter. But as a voter, I’m suddenly anxious. What if re-signing looks suspicious? What if it’s not allowed? The poll worker insists, but my mind races with the need to do things right, to follow the rules exactly. I feel torn, caught between my professional instinct for precision and my responsibility to follow the poll worker’s guidance. My hand hovers over the envelope, heart pounding, unsure which role to trust.
